trial_identification.studytitle: Assessment of free-living physical activity using a multi-sensor armband in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with and without co-morbid physical conditions
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Assessment of free-living physical activity on total energy expenditure using a multi-sensor armband in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with and without co-morbid physical conditions

interventions.interventions: Free-living physical activity over a seven day period. Free-living physical activity is the general activities of daily living generated by the subjects over the 24 hour day period including sleeping (excluding shower or water immersion)
interventions.comparator: COPD with no co-morbid physical condition will also undergo the free-living physical activity assessment over a seven day period

primaryOutcome.outcome: Total energy expenditure using the SenseWear Pro 3 Armband physical activity monitor which will be worn around the right triceps 24 hours a day (removed for shower or water immersion)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 24 hours a day for seven continuous days (removed only for shower or water immersion)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life via SF-36 questionnaire and St George's Respiratory Questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Initial assessment only, i.e. at baseline

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Functional performance via the Functional Performance Inventory questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Initial assessment only, i.e. at baseline

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Confirmed COPD with and without physical co-morbidities (eg. orthopaedic or musculoskeletal conditions affecting the lower limbs of lumbar spine +/- affecting range of motion, neurological conditions with residual effects affecting the lower limbs, obesity)
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Inability to understand English Completed a pulmonary rehabilitation program in the past 12 months Cognitive decline

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Aim is to determine the overall level of activity generated in everyday living by patients with COPD and co-morbidities compared to a COPD population without co-morbidities. The hypothesis is that people with COPD and co-morbid conditions generate less physical activity in every day living compared to people living with COPD with no co-morbid conditions.
